snippet: This year, there was more talk about tablet-size reading devices and 3-D television than about how to weather the economic storm.

headline.main: Optimism Takes Charge at Consumer Electronics Show
headline.print_headline: Optimism Takes Charge at an Electronics Show

byline.original: By BRAD STONE, ASHLEE VANCE, and JENNA WORTHAM

snippet: The mood at last week's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was decidedly more upbeat than at the previous year's show. At that exhibition, the chatter on the floor was less about innovation and breakthrough technologies than about how to weath...
abstract: Mood is considerably more optimistic at this year's Consumer Electronics Show, with talk of innovation and breakthrough technologies returning, as opposed to last year's discussions of how to weather economic storm that put damper on discretionary spending electronics industry relies on heavily; two-year-old start up Pixel Qi demonstrates its so-called dual-mode displays which features typical backlit color display of laptop screens, but at touch of button enters more readable black-and-white mode that consumes less power and would be perfect for next generation of e-readers; Lenovo shows off latest line of personal computers for consumer market, focusing heavily on design and flash; Palm shows latest versions of Pixi and Pre smartphones to help company expand number of United States carriers that offer Palm's products; photos (M)

headline.main: Optimism Takes Charge at an Electronics Show
